results.headline: A Brush With Internet Fame

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Damn!

results.summary_short: “Damn!” is more than just a documentary about a quirky New York gubernatorial candidate.

results.headline: A TV Host Seeks Fluff, but Real Life Intrudes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Scheherazade, Tell Me a Story

results.summary_short: Yousry Nasrallah’s “Scheherazade, Tell Me a Story” resets “The Arabian Nights” in modern-day Cairo.

results.headline: The Teenage Years in the Tumult of Afghanistan
results.display_title: The Boy Mir: Ten Years in Afghanistan

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Boy Mir: Ten Years in Afghanistan

results.summary_short: In “The Boy Mir,” Phil Grabsky returns to Afghanistan to follow the life of a boy who had been the subject of his earlier documentary.

results.headline: Death Will Not Be Cheated

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Final Destination 5

results.summary_short: Few horror cycles are as consistently true to their formulas as “Final Destination 5,” which hits all its marks.

results.headline: A Spectacular Rise and Fall

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Senna

results.summary_short: “Senna,” Asif Kapadia’s documentary on the Brazilian racecar driver Ayrton Senna, includes racing footage that is frequently heart-stopping.

results.headline: A Town Built for 30

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Darwin

results.summary_short: “Darwin” is Nick Brandestini’s portrait of a tiny California town nestled amid the arid landscapes of Death Valley.

results.headline: Young Tourists Marooned in a California Town

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Littlerock

results.summary_short: Two siblings visiting from Japan land in new territory when they are stranded in an out-of-the-way California town in “Littlerock.”

results.headline: A Tutorial on Tolerance, With Beats and Upbeats

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Glee The 3D Concert Movie

results.summary_short: “Glee: The 3D Concert Movie” notes just how terrific it is to be yourself.

results.headline: A Battle for India’s Soul

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Aarakshan

results.summary_short: In “Aarakshan,” a teacher in India battles the hucksters who want to make education a commodity available only to the privileged.

results.headline: Menu for Trouble: Pizza, a Stripper and Slackers With Weapons

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 30 Minutes or Less

results.summary_short: In “3o Minutes or Less” Jesse Eisenberg plays a pizza delivery man forced into a bank heist by a couple of slackers. It’s supposed to be a comedy.

results.headline: ‘The Maids’ Now Have Their Say

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Help

results.summary_short: “The Help,” Tate Taylor’s movie set in civil-rights-era Mississippi, shifts between black maids and their employers.

results.headline: Touring an Artist’s Pre-Apocalyptic Realm
results.display_title: Over Your Cities Grass Will Grow

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Over Your Cities Grass Will Grow

results.summary_short: Sophie Fiennes’s film “Over Your Cities Grass Will Grow” is a portrait of the painter and sculptor Anselm Kiefer at work and an exploration of the artistic compound he created in France.

results.headline: A Portuguese Tale of Time, the Revealer

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mysteries of Lisbon

results.summary_short: The sprawling “Mysteries of Lisbon,” an adaptation of the 19th-century novel by Camilo Castelo Branco, reassembles a life through the others that led to it.

results.headline: Swimming in Blood

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cold Fish

results.summary_short: Sion Sono’s “Cold Fish” is a deliciously warped wallow in misogyny, depravity and manipulation.

results.headline: A Souped-Up Romance Turns Demolition Derby

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bellflower

results.summary_short: The story of two friends who build muscle cars with flamethrowers in preparation for a global apocalypse is sweetened, just slightly, by a love affair.

results.headline: American in Bosnia Discovers the Horrors of Human Trafficking

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Whistleblower

results.summary_short: “The Whistleblower,” a film about a former United Nations peacekeeping officer, is a grueling exposé of human trafficking in postwar Bosnia.

results.headline: They Say Rock ’n’ Roll Will Never Die
results.display_title: The Perfect Age of Rock 'n' Roll

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Perfect Age of Rock 'n' Roll

results.summary_short: “The Perfect Age of Rock ’n’ Roll,” with Kevin Zegers as a rebounding rock star, piles up rock music clichés on the requisite road trip.

results.headline: About That Wish: What if It Came True?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Change-Up

results.summary_short: In the farcical bromance “The Change-Up,” an uptight corporate lawyer ends up in the body of what used to be called a “toxic bachelor.”

results.headline: Looking Apocalypse in the Eye
results.display_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rise of the Planet of the Apes

results.summary_short: “Rise of the Planet of the Apes” is both an origin story for its 1968 predecessor, “Planet of the Apes,” and an amusingly cheerful film about the end of humanity.

results.headline: Appeasing Nazis and a Wife

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Protektor

results.summary_short: In “Protektor,” Jana Plodkova stars as a Jewish starlet in Czechoslovakia worried about her career during the Nazi occupation.
